nodes.text: The degree of incumbency advantage (a measure of institutional flexibility) determines dynamic selection, persistence, and adaptability of governments; perfect democracy yields the most competent government in a nonstochastic environment, but any incumbency advantage can produce persistent bad governments while greater democracy increases adaptability to shocks

Model: dynamic discrete-time game where feasible governments are coalitions G, each G has competence u_G(t), individuals get utility from government competence and rents from membership, and transitions require a winning coalition characterized by thresholds m and l

Political equilibrium concept: a Markov political equilibrium maps each current government to either itself or an alternative that is preferred by a winning coalition and is not dominated by another feasible alternative; equilibria satisfy a recursive fixed-point characterization (mapping phi)
Nonstochastic result: Under perfect democracy (l=0) the unique stable equilibrium government is the most competent government (G1)

Nonstochastic counterresult: For any l >= 1 (any deviation from perfect democracy) there always exists at least one other stable government; the least competent government can be stable and persist forever

Stochastic result: When competencies change with rare shocks, greater democracy (lower l) increases the probability that the highest-competence government will come to power and improves long-run adaptability; perfect democracy immediately installs the best post-shock government while extreme dictatorship (l=k) blocks all change

Assumptions on preferences and institutions: (1) more competent governments give higher payoff all else equal; (2) membership grants additional rents so members prefer inclusion; (3) winning coalitions described by thresholds m_G and l_G; (4) competencies distinct across G

Game form specification (Appendix): explicit proposal and sequential voting procedure with unstable and sheltered states v_t, nomination protocol and primaries; Markov perfect equilibria of this extensive form coincide with political equilibria when discounting high and shocks infrequent

Equilibrium characterization: the phi mapping defined by ranking governments by competence and selecting, for each current government G, the least-ranked stable government preferred by a winning coalition yields the unique acyclic political equilibrium for sufficiently patient players

Implication: any incumbency advantage (l>0) can generate multiple basins of attraction and path dependence so the identity of the initial government strongly affects long-run competence under nonstochastic dynamics

Mechanism for persistence of bad governments: incremental reforms from a bad government can lead to unstable intermediates that exclude initial incumbents from final high-competence governments, so incumbents block changes and the initial bad government persists

Mechanism for stochastic flexibility: with rare stochastic shocks that reorder relative competencies, higher democracy reduces nearby stable governments and thus increases chance of large upward jumps to high-competence governments post-shock, producing greater long-run probability of best government

Comparative institutional insight: there is no monotone ranking of imperfect democracies and dictatorships in nonstochastic settings, but in stochastic environments greater democracy is unambiguously more flexible; royalty-like dictatorships (secure specific members) can outperform junta-like dictatorships under shocks when ability distribution is convex
Limitation: characterization and existence rely on high discount factors and infrequent shocks; frequent shocks or richer preference heterogeneity complicate equilibrium existence and structure

Research implication / future work: extend framework to asymmetric information about abilities, endogenous experimentation, incentive provision, richer voter heterogeneity, and mechanism design for institutions that ensure churning and adaptability
